data.title: The Blood of Hussain (1980)
data.meta_description: A dramatic depiction of the life of Hussain, with allegorical references to the history of the Prophet Muhammad and his descendants. It is prophesied that Young Hussain will one day lead the impoverished masses to a better life. It is his brother, Hasan, however who gains in prominence and when the government is overthrown in a military coup, he tries to adapt. Hussain in the meanwhile gets married and leads a small band of rebels in an attempt to fight the military dictatorship.
data.text:
This incredible Pakistani film was completed shortly before the 1977 coup in Pakistan and the coming to power of General Zia-ul-Haq. The story is a sort of modern re-telling of the legend of Karbala and Imam Hussain's struggle against the tyrannical rule of Yazid in the seventh century. Hussain in this film, like his ancient namesake, leads a band rebels against a tyrannical illegitimate government.

The story of Hussein has inspired countless works of poetry and passion plays over the centuries, and was bound to make its way to film. This controversial Pakistani film was completed shortly before the 1977 coup in Pakistan and the coming to power of General Zia-ul-Haq. The story is a sort of modern re-telling of the legend of Karbala and Imam Hussain's struggle against the tyrannical rule of Yazid in the seventh century. Hussain in this film, like his ancient namesake, leads a band of rebels against a tyrannical illegitimate government.

A responsibility of selflessness, compassion, and community conflicts with the desire to understand oneself, to become impersonal for the sake of a happy life. Hussain, our lead finds the worst in both extremes – a sobering discovery in modern times. His fortress, or his homestead, mountains surrounding the mystical city of Lahore is his…

Pakistan is historically disadvantaged in cinema history, though probably not only there. Its neighbour India is outreaching it, whether it is Bollywood blockbusters or the renowned arthouse cinema of the Rays, Sens or Ghataks. Yet Pakistan has to struggle with at least similarly complex problems. And, as Jamil Dehlavi proves, he knows how to capture them in equally lyrical and epic images. "The Blood of Hussain" is a film that combines awe-inspiring mysticism and political explosiveness for eternity.
